channel.description: The top News headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit https://www.smh.com.au
channel.title: Sydney Morning Herald - Latest News

item.dc:creator: Latika Bourke
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: Coronavirus updates LIVE: More than 30 million Americans thrown out of work as global COVID-19 cases surpass 3.2 million, Australian death toll stands at 92

item.description: Mikhail Mishustin, one of the main co-ordinators of Russia's response to the new coronavirus, is the first high-ranking Russian official diagnosed with the virus.
item.title: Russian Prime Minister tests positive for coronavirus

item.description: Intelligence agencies have debunked a conspiracy theory, saying they have concluded that the new coronavirus was "not man-made or genetically modified".
item.title: US spy agency says COVID-19 'not man-made', still studying lab theory

item.description: One man was shot in the chest and another in the arm as they sat in a car outside a home in Merrylands, police say.
item.title: Man critically injured in double shooting in Sydney's west

item.description: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits because of the coronavirus has soared past 30 million, worsening a crisis unmatched since the 1930s.
item.title: US jobless claims soar past 30 million as Europe also reels

item.description: Follow our rolling coverage.
item.title: Tablet interactive: Coronavirus outbreak

item.dc:creator: Miki Perkins
item.description: Thousands of hectares of native forest devastated by the catastrophic summer fires are about to be logged by state-owned companies.
item.title: Logging returns to NSW native forests hit by bushfires

item.dc:creator: Fergus Hunter
item.description: More than 1300 mobile network towers and other facilities were knocked out during the unprecedented bushfire crisis.
item.title: More than 1300 mobile towers and nodes went down during the bushfires

item.dc:creator: Phil Lutton
item.description: Some of Australia's swimming stars have been given clearance to train but uncertainty lingers ahead of a barren sporting calendar and questions over Tokyo 2021.
item.title: Olympic champion Chalmers back in pool as long road to Games begins

item.dc:creator: Darren Gray
item.description: Maurice Blackburn alleges Treasury had problems in the Americas much earlier than the Penfolds maker told the market.
item.title: Treasury Wine facing second class action over US disclosures

item.dc:creator: Alexandra Smith
item.description: New heat maps will for the first time reveal active coronavirus cases by postcode, revealing how many people have the virus, test numbers and recovery rates.
item.title: Coronavirus by postcode: NSW launches Australian-first heat maps

item.dc:creator: Zoe Samios
item.description: Small publishers are concerned about the unintended consequences that could come from forcing Google and Facebook to pay for news content.
item.title: ACCC vows to protect smaller publishers in Google, Facebook talks

item.dc:creator: Peter Hannam
item.description: Australian taxpayers have funnelled $40 billion into water-saving works into our main food bowl only to fund even greater extraction at the expense of small farms and the environment.
item.title: 'Rebound effect' drains even more water from Murray-Darling Basin

item.description: Free daily horoscope for each star sign from renowned Astrologer Hedy Damari. Forecasts for the day ahead in life, love and career.
item.title: Your Daily Horoscope for Friday, May 1

item.dc:creator: Bob Carr
item.description: Australia has blundered into a diplomatic disaster. Itâ€™s extraordinary that the deterioration in our relationship with Beijing means no one can pick up the phone and say an open inquiry into the coronavirus is in its interests.
item.title: Once again we look like diplomatic amateurs on China

item.description: Previous economic crises inform us of the dire mental health impacts of the pandemic unless we take the same kind of decisive actions that have succeeded against the coronavirus itself.
item.title: Now let's flatten the mental health curve

item.description: The essential weapon in our armoury against COVID-19 is the community's propensity to do the right thing.
item.title: We kept our distance before the COVID decrees: phone data reveals Australians' goodwill

item.description: In the dark of pandemic it is the softness that dies first. The softness of intelligent diplomacy is, right now, dying from under-use.
item.title: PM crash tackles China when soft diplomacy is needed

item.description: A life-and-death crisis such as the coronavirus forces us to value the people who can help - and to place less stock in the ideological posturings of inexpert commentators.
item.title: At last, we prefer experts to noisy pretenders

item.dc:creator: Lissa Christopher
item.description: Found yourself with a new puppy or a rescue dog? Here are five books that will help you navigate your new relationship.Â
item.title: Five books about dog behaviour (in case you've recently acquired one)

item.dc:creator: Cara Waters
item.description: With regular Friday evening drinks off the cards for the time being, some workplaces are offering fun alternatives like online art classes, Zoom workouts and pickling lessons.
item.title: Painting and pickling: Working from home for Australia's top tech company

item.dc:creator: Kerrie O'Brien
item.description: Struggling to get your finances in order? Check out these straightforward books about personal finance.
item.title: Five guides to financial freedom (for the layperson)

item.description: Over its 32 years of operation, the Sydney Entertainment Centre played host to some of rock music's biggest names, including Queen, Elton John and U2.
item.title: From the Archives, 1983: $41m 'butterbox' opens with a bang

item.dc:creator: Harry Hollinsworth
item.description: Counting underway, Anderson angry, and Pele weds again.
item.title: In the Herald: May 1, 1994

item.description: An executive producer at SBS with a sideline as a marriage celebrant notes many couples are holding smaller, more affordable weddings amid the coronavirus pandemic.
item.title: Match made in heaven: Journo delivers the news and spreads the love

item.dc:creator: Kylar Loussikian
item.description: An unfair dismissal case by AMP's former litigation boss against the financial services giant is turning into quite a spectacle. And the showâ€™s only just begun.
item.title: Naming in Baker Cook case could be recipe for strife

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted by our talented artists, illustrators and cartoonists.
item.title: Best of cartoons, May 1, 2020

item.dc:creator: Eryk Bagshaw
item.description: Australia will support Taiwan's return to the World Health Organisation as an observer four years after it was ousted by Beijing.
item.title: Australia to back Taiwan's return to the WHO

item.dc:creator: Timna Jacks
item.description: Those returning to Melbourne's trains, trams and buses as lockdown measures ease will findÂ standing cheek-by-jowl with other commuters is a thing of the past.Â
item.title: Mind the gap: What your journey to work could look like after lockdown

item.dc:creator: Nathanael Cooper
item.description: Social restrictions may be starting to ease but gigs aren't back yet - here's how to stay in touch.
item.title: From boylesque to Ali Barter's house: this weekend's top gigs

item.description: Planning in France was brought to an abrupt halt by a declaration by the prime minister, Ã‰douard Philippe. The French soccer season, the prime minister announced, was over.
item.title: Franceâ€™s prime minister shut down soccer. Did he make the right call?

item.dc:creator: Dana McCauley
item.description: Aged care operators will allow controlled visits by family members where safe to do so under a draft voluntary code of practice to be unveiled on Friday.Â
item.title: Aged care code of practice to allow controlled visits by family members

item.description: The news of the day as interpreted in the work of our award-winning cartoonists.
item.title: Today's cartoons: The illustrated news

item.dc:creator: David Crowe
item.description: Scott Morrison has played the politics hard but his message appeals to parents who are frustrated, as it seems the health crisis is being brought under control.
item.title: Morrison's classrooms push has plenty of smoke and mirrors

item.description: I find myself again in a kind of prison, waiting for release.
item.title: I survived the Holocaust. Now I wait for freedom again

item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating an aircraft incident at Hawthorne Airport last Friday involving the Indiana Jones actor.
item.title: Harrison Ford again under FAA investigation after new aircraft incident

item.dc:creator: Anthony Colangelo
item.description: The man faced court charged over what is believed to be one of the biggest armed robberies in Victoria's history.
item.title: Man charged over armed robbery at Melbourne gold dealer

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: If you suspect you or a family member has coronavirus you should call (not visit) your GP or ring the national Coronavirus Health Information Hotline on 1800 020 080.
item.title: As the day unfolded: Scott Morrison urges further downloads of COVIDSafe, global COVID-19 infections climb past 3.1 million as nation's death toll stands at 92

item.description: Trivia and word buffs: test your knowledge with today's superquiz and Target.
item.title: Target and superquiz, Friday, May 1

item.dc:creator: Michael Chammas
item.description: NRL faces broadcast shortfall of up to $81m as Foxtel follows Nine's lead and seeks further price reduction.
item.title: Foxtel seeks multimillion-dollar discount for resumed NRL season

item.dc:creator: Heather McNeill
item.description: Prosecutors will call two witnesses the defence has requested to cross-examine before the court crosses to the UK to again hear from international fibres expert, Dr Ray Palmer.
item.title: Claremont killer trial: 'Very strong chance Ciara Glennon was in accused's car': Fibre expert

item.dc:creator: David Prestipino
item.description: WA's Police Commissioner says the Dockers trio caught out partying with a group of people last Sunday would not be probed any further for potential breaches of the state's coronavirus restrictions.
item.title: 'Nothing to see here': Partying Dockers get a pass from WA's top cop

item.dc:creator: Anna Patty
item.description: Pressure is mounting on the NSW and federal governments to respond to calls for help to support jobless international students.
item.title: Business and unions urge governments to help jobless foreign students

item.description: Mandurah Police have appealed for urgent assistance from the public regarding the whereabouts of Peter Henry Woods after he left his residence, about 70km south of Perth, at about 9.30pm on April 27.
item.title: Mandurah police hold concerns for welfare of missing 66-year-old man

item.description: Statistics show that 115 per cent of people are losing the plot.
item.title: Learning more than the curriculum at home

item.dc:creator: Paul Sakkal
item.description: More rain has fallen on the city in the first four months of 2020 than in the whole of last year, and Friday will bring more cold weather and heavy downpours.
item.title: Melbourne marks wettest April since 1960 as snow blankets ski resorts

item.dc:creator: Matt Bungard
item.description: Two Highway Patrol unit officers were taken to Nepean Hospital on Thursday evening after their parked vehicle was allegedly struck by Land Rover on Hawkesbury Road.
item.title: NSW police officers injured after Blue Mountains crash

item.dc:creator: Adam Pengilly
item.description: What needs to happen for the NRL to return on its proposed start date of May 28.
item.title: The questions you need answered about the NRL and its return

item.dc:creator: Stuart Layt
item.description: While our phones could help halt the spread of coronavirus through the new tracing app, research shows they could also be spreading it.
item.title: Filthy mobile phones found to be germ-riddled 'Trojan horses'

item.dc:creator: Lydia Lynch
item.description: The potential bungle was uncovered after another state-owned supplier, Sunwater, underpaid up to 400 of its staff over a decade.
item.title: State-owned water supplier may have underpaid 100 staff for years
